I have just read your letter concerning Will E. I regard the matter in the same light that you do, and think it a cruel, 
                                                                           226
wicked thing that the father of Will E should take the course that he is taking, but I have not dared to answer his letters. If anything can come from me through you to him, I would say that his case cannot be improved by leaving the present wife. It would not better the case to go to the other woman in the question. . . .
